channel.title: Encoding multiple values into one variable
channel.description:
So, I was just fiddling around with a bunch of different ideas, which is something I do often when I'm bored. I came across a post somewhere on Stack Overflow where someone had posted this to a question: [u][b]http://stackoverflow.com/a/20173929[/b][/u].
Now, I was wondering...what if you could encode one integer using multiple bytes and then reverse the integer to the state without the encoding by only knowing the length of the bytes and the currently encoded integer.
I have tried using masks and a whole bunch of diddly squat that doesn't even get close to what I need. Would anyone know of a way or algorithm this can be achieved or if it's even possible.

@T41 wrote:

i can store all of the data in the universe in this one byte, i call it cosmic compression.

item.source: Encoding multiple values into one variable

item.title: Encoding multiple values into one variable
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Well, it’s not so much that it isn’t great. In some situations it makes total sense. If you have a ton of boolean values for some reason, and you are network constrained or on an embedded system or some other time where memory is an issue, it may indeed make sense to store them as a bitmask - you can then fit 8 of them in one byte, as you mentioned.

This isn’t compression, though. It works because the default type for bool (in C, I’m talking, though obviously the same principles apply in Java with different types/sizes) is 8 bits wide, and you only need to store 1 bit of information. So, by storing it in a more memory-optimal way, you can fit 8 bits in what would previously be one ‘bool’.

You haven’t compressed anything though, just stored it more optimally. If you need to store x bits of information, you either need x bits of space, minimum, or, you need to use some sort of compression algorithm that allows you to reduce the space needed (which will be specific to the data you’re storing - there is no generic compression algorithm guaranteed to reduce the size of any file, it’s mathematically impossible).

And you certainly can’t store infinite bits in one byte. That is just obviously physically impossible.

Read full topic

item.title: Encoding multiple values into one variable
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:20, topic:549006”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=667915.msg4467002#msg4467002 date=1420670433]
You can not compress it down with a single bit with your algorithm.
[/quote]
I think we have already established that you ignorant dick.[/quote]
You asked if you could compress it down with 87.5% (10 GB to 125 MB). And I answered you that you couldn’t make the file even one bit smaller with your algorithm/idea. How is that being ignorant?

If you want to learn about compression, look it up and not make up stupid ideas like this.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

Bowser jr:

You can not compress it down with a single bit with your algorithm.

I think we have already established that you ignorant dick.

[quote=“Mopman, post:19, topic:549006”]OH MY GOD YOU’RE A GENIUS, WE CAN NOW DELIVER NETFLIX OVER 1BYTE/SEC! YOU’VE FIXED THEIR CONGESTION ISSUES! AND THE MARS ROVER GUYS ARE GONNA BE REALLY HAPPY.

EDIT: But taking my dickhead hat off, yeah this really makes no sense, sorry.[/quote]
It makes sense to want to have an amazing compression. My background is byte compression isn’t great at all, as you would obviously notice. The best way to answer any question is to give a good answer, not a shitty one.

I’ll stick to byte pair encoding for now.

item.source: Encoding multiple values into one variable

item.title: Encoding multiple values into one variable
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:16, topic:549006”][quote author=Lin link=topic=667915.msg4466987#msg4466987 date=1420655493]

You know that files have a minimum size depending on the file system? You gain no benefit of having lots of small files.

Are you talking about the OS file system, or the file encoding? Also, I’m not going to split a file into multiple files.

10GB File -> My compression:

[ul][li]The file is placed into my compressor[/li]
[li]The file bytes are all encoded into one byte[/li]
[li]The file compressed is now only 5 bytes, the encoded value, and the length of the bytes of the regular file[/li]
[li]This is the part where I figure out how to decompress, not known yet[/li][/ul]

[/quote]I… don’t really know how to respond. It’s literally impossible to compress any combination of bytes into just 8 bits, because with 8 bits you have literally only 256 possible values. It sounds like what you’re wanting to do is index files, where you store the uncompressed file somewhere else and file 0 will load that file. That’s the only way to do it, unless you manage to figure out some efficient algorithm that’s capable of generating all 256 of your unique files from a single byte, which you won’t.

So, do you think it’s possible to compress 1GB to 125MB? That’s number you would get from 1GB divided by 8. So, if I could encode every 8 bytes, I could get a pretty successful output.[/quote]
encode every 8 bytes into what? to represent the data therein, you’d have to use 8 bytes (unless you have other algorithms. like if you have 8 0s in a row, write 8x0 rather than 00000000 [really simple type of compression])

Read full topic

You know that files have a minimum size depending on the file system? You gain no benefit of having lots of small files.

Are you talking about the OS file system, or the file encoding? Also, I’m not going to split a file into multiple files.

10GB File -> My compression:

[ul][li]The file is placed into my compressor[/li]
[li]The file bytes are all encoded into one byte[/li]
[li]The file compressed is now only 5 bytes, the encoded value, and the length of the bytes of the regular file[/li]
[li]This is the part where I figure out how to decompress, not known yet[/li][/ul]

[/quote]I… don’t really know how to respond. It’s literally impossible to compress any combination of bytes into just 8 bits, because with 8 bits you have literally only 256 possible values. It sounds like what you’re wanting to do is index files, where you store the uncompressed file somewhere else and file 0 will load that file. That’s the only way to do it, unless you manage to figure out some efficient algorithm that’s capable of generating all 256 of your unique files from a single byte, which you won’t.[/quote]
So, do you think it’s possible to compress 1GB to 125MB? That’s number you would get from 1GB divided by 8. So, if I could encode every 8 bytes, I could get a pretty successful output.

item.title: Encoding multiple values into one variable
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:8, topic:549006”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=667915.msg4466962#msg4466962 date=1420648254]
When do you have millions of boolean values and not much of any other value that makes this advantageous? Java makes everything into a int (bool, short and int iirc) because this would make the program faster at looking up the values. And compressing something to 1/32 of it’s size isn’t that impressive.

Why would you make those kind of optimazitions unless you know that it would be a bottleneck?
[/quote]
I didn’t say a single word about booleans. I’m talking about bytes of a file being compressed into one integer.[/quote]
That wouldn’t help you compress anything. Files are stored byte for byte,not 4 bytes at the time.

Read full topic

item.source: Encoding multiple values into one variable

item.title: Encoding multiple values into one variable
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

Bowser jr:

Why are you doing this? Unless you have an huge amount of bools, I don’t see why you would do this.

I had a hypothesis. If I can have multiple values encoded into one integer or byte, then I could compress trillions and quadrillions of bytes into a couple kilos and have the world’s fastest and best compression. Of course, this is pretty much impossible at the moment without knowing the values to encode with.

eg

public static byte[] compress(byte[] input) {
	byte[] compressed = new byte[1];
	for (int i = 0; i < input.length; i++) {
		compressed[0] |= input[i]; // encoding every bit into one (not converted atm)
	}
	byte[] lengthToBytes = ByteBuffer.allocate(4).putInt(input.length).array();
	compressed = Arrays.copyOf(compressed, lengthToBytes.length + compressed.length);
	for (int i = 0; i < lengthToBytes.length; i++)
		compressed[1 + i] = lengthToBytes[i]; // the first byte is the entire stack of bytes
	return compressed;
}

Now how would I decompress those values if I only know the encoded value and the length of the bytes?

Maybe something like this?

public static byte[] decompress(byte[] input) {
	int length = ByteBuffer.wrap(Arrays.copyOfRange(input, 1, input.length)).getInt();
	byte[] decompressed = new byte[length]; //encoded value
	for (byte b = Byte.MIN_VALUE; b < Byte.MAX_VALUE; b++) {
		if ((input[0] & (1 << b)) != 0) {
			decompressed[0] = (byte) (input[0] & (1 << b));
			break;
		}
	}
	return decompressed;
}

Read full topic

item.source: Encoding multiple values into one variable

item.title: Encoding multiple values into one variable
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:1, topic:549006”]So, I was just fiddling around with a bunch of different ideas, which is something I do often when I’m bored. I came across a post somewhere on Stack Overflow where someone had posted this to a question: http://stackoverflow.com/a/20173929.

Now, I was wondering…what if you could encode one integer using multiple bytes and then reverse the integer to the state without the encoding by only knowing the length of the bytes and the currently encoded integer.

I have tried using masks and a whole bunch of diddly squat that doesn’t even get close to what I need. Would anyone know of a way or algorithm this can be achieved or if it’s even possible.[/quote]

It depends on the values you want to put. If you want to store boolean values, you could use 1 int to represent 32 distinct booleans. if you want to store 2-bit values, you could represent 16 of those with an int. But, in order to get any real meaning out of them, you would have to do something like

public boolean isEnabled(final int mask, final int value) {
    return value & mask;
}

And

private static final int FIRST_FIELD_MASK = 0b00000000000000000000000000000001;// or 0x01
private static final int SECOND_FIELD_MASK = 0b00000000000000000000000000000010;// or 0x02

public void checkIfValueContainsFirstField(final int value) {
    return isEnabled(FIRST_FIELD_MASK, value);
}

But, by doing this, you’re adding a lot of extra code, and creating a maintenance nightmare. You shouldn’t be prematurely optimizing. Make it work, make it work well, and make it work better. I mean, you should never really have to look into optimizing down to a bit level anyways, as the compiler will probably do it better than you ever can anyway.

Read full topic
item.source: Encoding multiple values into one variable
